paragraphs.content: Chapter 10
paragraphs.contentHtml: Chapter 10

paragraphs.content: Dead flies cause the ointment of the apothecary to send forth a stinking savour: so doth a little folly him that is in reputation for wisdom and honour.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Dead flies cause the ointment of the apothecary to send forth a stinking savour: so doth a little folly him that is in reputation for wisdom and honour.

paragraphs.content: A wise man’s heart is at his right hand; but a fool’s heart at his left.
paragraphs.contentHtml: A wise man’s heart is at his right hand; but a fool’s heart at his left.

paragraphs.content: Yea also, when he that is a fool walketh by the way, his wisdom faileth him, and he saith to every one that he is a fool.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Yea also, when he that is a fool walketh by the way, his wisdom faileth him, and he saith to every one that he is a fool.

paragraphs.content: If the spirit of the ruler rise up against thee, leave not thy place; for yielding pacifieth great offences.
paragraphs.contentHtml: If the spirit of the ruler rise up against thee, leave not thy place; for yielding pacifieth great offences.

paragraphs.content: There is an evil which I have seen under the sun, as an error which proceedeth from the ruler:
paragraphs.contentHtml: There is an evil which I have seen under the sun, as an error which proceedeth from the ruler:

paragraphs.content: Folly is set in great dignity, and the rich sit in low place.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Folly is set in great dignity, and the rich sit in low place.

paragraphs.content: I have seen servants upon horses, and princes walking as servants upon the earth.
paragraphs.contentHtml: I have seen servants upon horses, and princes walking as servants upon the earth.

paragraphs.content: He that diggeth a pit shall fall into it; and whoso breaketh an hedge, a serpent shall bite him.
paragraphs.contentHtml: He that diggeth a pit shall fall into it; and whoso breaketh an hedge, a serpent shall bite him.

paragraphs.content: Whoso removeth stones shall be hurt therewith; and he that cleaveth wood shall be endangered thereby.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Whoso removeth stones shall be hurt therewith; and he that cleaveth wood shall be endangered thereby.

paragraphs.content: If the iron be blunt, and he do not whet the edge, then must he put to more strength: but wisdom is profitable to direct.
paragraphs.contentHtml: If the iron be blunt, and he do not whet the edge, then must he put to more strength: but wisdom is profitable to direct.

paragraphs.content: Surely the serpent will bite without enchantment; and a babbler is no better.
paragraphs.contentHtml: Surely the serpent will bite without enchantment; and a babbler is no better.

paragraphs.content: The words of a wise man’s mouth are gracious; but the lips of a fool will swallow up himself.
paragraphs.contentHtml: The words of a wise man’s mouth are gracious; but the lips of a fool will swallow up himself.

paragraphs.content: The beginning of the words of his mouth is foolishness: and the end of his talk is mischievous madness.
paragraphs.contentHtml: The beginning of the words of his mouth is foolishness: and the end of his talk is mischievous madness.

paragraphs.content: A fool also is full of words: a man cannot tell what shall be; and what shall be after him, who can tell him?
paragraphs.contentHtml: A fool also is full of words: a man cannot tell what shall be; and what shall be after him, who can tell him?

paragraphs.content: The labour of the foolish wearieth every one of them, because he knoweth not how to go to the city.
paragraphs.contentHtml: The labour of the foolish wearieth every one of them, because he knoweth not how to go to the city.

paragraphs.content: ¶ Woe to thee, O land, when thy king is a child, and thy princes eat in the morning!
paragraphs.contentHtml: ¶ Woe to thee, O land, when thy king is a child, and thy princes eat in the morning!

paragraphs.content: Blessed art thou, O land, when thy king is the son of nobles, and thy princes eat in due season, for strength, and not for drunkenness!
paragraphs.contentHtml: Blessed art thou, O land, when thy king is the son of nobles, and thy princes eat in due season, for strength, and not for drunkenness!

paragraphs.content: ¶ By much slothfulness the building decayeth; and through idleness of the hands the house droppeth through.
paragraphs.contentHtml: ¶ By much slothfulness the building decayeth; and through idleness of the hands the house droppeth through.

paragraphs.content: ¶ A feast is made for laughter, and wine maketh merry: but money answereth all things.
paragraphs.contentHtml: ¶ A feast is made for laughter, and wine maketh merry: but money answereth all things.

paragraphs.content: ¶ Curse not the king, no not in thy thought; and curse not the rich in thy bedchamber: for a bird of the air shall carry the voice, and that which hath wings shall tell the matter.
paragraphs.contentHtml: ¶ Curse not the king, no not in thy thought; and curse not the rich in thy bedchamber: for a bird of the air shall carry the voice, and that which hath wings shall tell the matter.
